awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Inquiry at the Forefront of Energy, Environmental, and Biochemical Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities, located in Minneapolis, MN, supports the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Science Directorate, participants work on addressing some of society's important biochemical, energy, and environmental problems at a major research university using top facilities and instrumentation. The participants' research experiences are supplemented with extensive hands-on training and mentoring. All participants deliver presentations on their summer research, participate in an end-of-summer research symposium, and have an opportunity to present their work at a national chemistry meeting. Professional development is fostered by a visit to a local industrial or government laboratory and by weekly joint luncheons for all fellows with topics on ethics, effective oral and written communication, and career opportunities. To increase the program's impact and sense of community among the participants, undergraduate students are encouraged to volunteer for an outreach program that gives children the opportunity to perform hands-on chemistry experiments at local community libraries.

The individual research projects encompass a wide range of chemical research, including multimetallic catalysts for small-molecule activation and functionalization, modeling structure and reactivity in molecular systems, studying protein-protein interactions, and synthesis and self-assembly of renewable resource block polymers. This program's recruitment effort places an emphasis on attracting underrepresented minority and economically disadvantaged students and encouraging participants to consider careers in chemistry-related fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Chemistry Department at the University of Minnesota hosted 35 undergraduate students over 4 summers to carry out individual research projects in highly interdisciplinary areas at the forefront of chemistry. Students worked on problems addressing society's most important human health, energy, and environmental problems. All participants were from schools other than the University of Minnesota Twin Cities campus. Underrepresented minority groups and the economically disadvantaged were targeted to maximize the program impact and lead students to consider careers in chemistry-related fields who might otherwise choose different career paths. Students from community colleges, sophomores (who are often not sure yet about their career aspirations), and students from institutions with limited research opportunities were targeted with complementary strategies, i.e., by national advertisements and through new and existing personal contacts with undergraduate institutions that have sent minority and community college students to the department or to partnering departments on campus. To increase the program impact and sense of community among the participants, they were encouraged to volunteer on several Saturday afternoons for the outreach program Chemists-in-the-Library (organized by PI Buhlmann) that gives children the opportunity to perform hands-on chemistry experiments at local community libraries, almost all of which are in neighborhoods with large minority communities (see attached photo). This program was invited in 2024 to present on this program at the American Chemical Society (ACS) fall meeting in the session organized by the ACS President on outstanding ACS initiatives.

Participants gained challenging research experiences in a nurturing environment at a major research university using top facilities and instrumentation. Their research experience was supplemented with extensive hands-on training and professional mentoring. All students gave oral presentations on their summer research, participated in an end-of-summer research symposium where they could interact with undergraduates from local colleges, and had an opportunity to present their work at a national chemistry meeting during the following academic year. Professional development was fostered by one visit each summer to a local industrial or government laboratory as well as by a weekly joint luncheon for all fellows with topics on ethics, effective oral and written communication, and career opportunities. Optional activities for interested students included instrumentation training, library tutorials, and classes at the Minnesota Supercomputer Institute as well as a variety of social activities with faculty, graduate students, and postdocs, where mentoring occurs in an informal setting.

All students also worked on an individual development plan (IDP). The program identified four categories of skills that it wanted to help the fellows improve over their summer: (a) experimental/computational design, (b) experimental/computational skills/technique, (c) experimental/computational data interpretation, and (d) scientific presentation ability. In prior years, the program coordinators had noticed though that individual students had different needs and interests. Therefore, they asked the fellows at the start of the program to identify two categories of skills that they wanted to focus on in particular. They suggested that these be areas in which the fellows would benefit most from improving, although fellows had the opportunity to also identify other areas in which they wanted to improve. The fellows were then asked to discuss these areas with their graduate student and faculty mentors to determine what they could do to improve those skills and make a plan for what they would do over the summer to improve those skills. PI Buhlmann met every summer each fellow individually in the 5th or 6th week of the program to discuss with them how they perceived their progress towards their IDP goals and what they could do for the remainder of the program to progress further. Through the entire program period, all but one fellow reported at that time that they had already made significant progress towards their IDP goals. In the case of that particular student, PI Buhlmann intervened and had a discussion with the faculty mentor to remediate the situation.

The summer undergraduate researchers were also invited to events of the Community of Chemistry Graduate Students to promote networking and socializing, and help prevent stress and mental health symptoms before they arise. The department is proud to be among the most active chemistry departments in the nation in addressing stress and mental health, not only in directing students in distress to proper resources but also by improving the department climate and productivity by openly talking about this topic (see the article in J. Chem. Ed. entitled Stress and Mental Health in Graduate School: How Student Empowerment Creates Lasting Change, http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.jchemed.8b00188).
